---
title: "Retail Orders Database"
format: revealjs
---

## 1. Customers Table

Description: This table stores customer information. It contains the "who" – all the customer details including their first name, last name, and contact email. Each customer gets a unique ID.

::: {style="font-size: 0.8em;"}
| customer_id | first_name | last_name | email |
|------------|-----------|----------|------------------------|
| 1 | John | Doe | john.doe@example.com |
| 2 | Jane | Smith | jane.smith@example.com |
| 3 | Robert | Johnson | robert.johnson@example.com |
| 4 | Sarah | Williams | sarah.williams@example.com |
:::

## 2. Products Table

Description: This table stores product information. It contains the "what" – all available products with their pricing and descriptions. Each product gets a unique ID.

::: {style="font-size: 0.8em;"}
| product_id | name | price | description |
|-----------|----------------|--------|-------------------------|
| 1 | Silk Blouse | 89.99 | Elegant office wear |
| 2 | Denim Jeans | 79.99 | Classic straight cut |
| 3 | Cashmere Sweater | 149.99 | Soft winter essential |
| 4 | Leather Jacket | 249.99 | Stylish outerwear |
:::

## 3. Orders Table

Description: This table links customers and products together. It records the "transaction" – which customer ordered which product and when. The customer_id and product_id columns refer back to the Customers and Products tables.

::: {style="font-size: 0.8em;"}
| order_id | customer_id | product_id | order_date |
|----------|------------|-----------|---------------------|
| 1 | 1 | 3 | 2025-06-10 14:30:00 |
| 2 | 2 | 1 | 2025-07-15 09:15:00 |
| 3 | 3 | 2 | 2025-08-02 16:45:00 |
| 4 | 2 | 4 | 2025-08-18 11:20:00 |
| 5 | 4 | 1 | 2025-08-25 13:10:00 |
:::
